Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Self-Hypnotic Relaxation for Pain and Anxiety Management in Outpatient Breast Biopsy

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to standard care (n=76), structured empathic attention (n=82), or self-hypnotic relaxation (n=78).

Participants.evidence: 236 women referred to an urban tertiary university-affiliated medical center. Eligibility criteria included adult women undergoing biopsy.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to standard care (n=76), structured empathic attention (n=82), or self-hypnotic relaxation (n=78).

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the effectiveness of adjunct self-hypnotic relaxation during large core needle breast biopsy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was self-rated pain and anxiety on 0–10 verbal analog scales, measured at 10-minute intervals.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomised to standard care (n=76), structured empathic attention (n=82), or self-hypnotic relaxation (n=78).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Anxiety increased significantly in the standard group (logit slope = 0.18, p < 0.001), did not change in the empathy group (slope = −0.04, p = 0.45), and decreased significantly in the hypnosis group (slope = −0.27, p < 0.001).
